text: DONALD TRUMP: It'll be great.
It'll happen.

-You're going to do health
care and tax reform?

DONALD TRUMP: We'll
see what happens.

No particular rush, but
we'll see what happens.

But health care is
coming along well.

Government is coming
along really well.

A lot of good things
are happening.
Thank you, folks.
[interposing voices]

DONALD TRUMP: Doesn't
matter if it's next week.
Next week doesn't matter.

-Are you going to do
Dodd-Frank this year?
Dodd-Frank reform this year?

DONALD TRUMP: We're doing very
well on Dodd-Frank, believe me.
Thank you.
-Thank you, Mr President.

-So again, that was just
moments ago as he's leaving
the Treasury Department.

I want to bring in CNN political
analyst Alex Burns sitting
with me here in New York.

You were there too when
we heard his remarks

when he signed some of those
executive financial orders.

We heard at the end of
that him saying Wednesday
is going to be a big day.

You're going to hear a big
announcement on tax reform.

Now, it seems like he's
dialing it back a little bit.

ALEX BURNS: Well, and this is
part of the sort of confusion

that's emanating from
the White House right

now, that on the one hand you
hear from the president-- we

heard from him on Twitter
this morning that 100 days is

a nonsense deadline, next
week, we just heard him say,
is not a big deal.

On the other hand, the
White House clearly

is using next week and
this 100 day deadline

as a way to try to spur
some of these slow moving

members of Congress to
do something, right?

And it's the something
that's the big question
mark right now.

-So you think it's
to put more pressure

on Congress through some of
the rhetoric we're hearing?

ALEX BURNS: I think it's
a combination of applying

pressure to Congress, and
then frankly just galvanizing

themselves to get moving again
on some of these big issues

that have really just
been frozen in place,

or seemed frozen in place,
over the last months

since the collapse of the
first health care legislation.
